target_sent: Come, come, I am a king, Masters, know you that?
source_sent: -   You, sir, more knave than Fool, after your master.

target_sent: -  O Fool, I shall go mad!
source_sent: -   You, sir, more knave than Fool, after your master.

target_sent: I know not what to say.
source_sent: Remember what I have said.

target_sent: I have noted it well.

target_sent: Dost thou call me "fool"boy?
source_sent: Now, by my life, Old fools are babes again and must be used With checks as flatteries, when they are seen abused.

target_sent: I am old and foolish.
source_sent: As you are old and reverend, should be wise.

target_sent: -   Poor Fool and knave, I have one part in my heart That's sorry yet for thee.

I'll pray, and then I'll sleep.
source_sent: I will not sleep, my lord, till I have delivered your letter.

target_sent: -  Come, bring us to this hovel.
source_sent: Gracious my lord, hard by here is a hovel.

target_sent: Kent, on thy life, no more.
source_sent: Be Kent unmannerly When Lear is mad.

target_sent: The King would speak with Cornwall.
source_sent: I thought the King had more affected the Duke of Albany than Cornwall.

target_sent: O heavens, If you do love old men, if your sweet sway Allow obedience, if you yourselves are old, Make it your cause.
source_sent: What wouldst thou do, old man?

target_sent: I am the King himself.
source_sent: I will go seek the King.

target_sent: I am old and foolish.
source_sent: Sir, I am too old to learn.

target_sent: Thou serv'st me, and I'll love thee.
source_sent: The gods to their dear shelter take thee, maid, That justly think'st and hast most rightly said.

target_sent: -   Cordelia, Cordelia, stay a little.
source_sent: If you shall see Cordelia (As fear not but you shall), show her this ring, And she will tell you who that fellow is That yet you do not know.

target_sent: This tempest will not give me leave to ponder On things would hurt me more.
source_sent: Some friendship will it lend you 'gainst the tempest.

target_sent: -   Poor Fool and knave, I have one part in my heart That's sorry yet for thee.
source_sent: Good my lord, You have begot me, bred me, loved me.

target_sent: Therefore begone Without our grace, our love, our benison.
source_sent: Good my lord, You have begot me, bred me, loved me.

target_sent: Hide thee, thou bloody hand, Thou perjured, and thou simular of virtue That art incestuous.
source_sent: Haply, when I shall wed, That lord whose hand must take my plight shall carry Half my love with him, half my care and duty.

target_sent: Thy truth, then, be thy dower, For by the sacred radiance of the sun, The mysteries of Hecate and the night, By all the operation of the orbs From whom we do exist and cease to be, Here I disclaim all my paternal care, Propinquity, and property of blood, And as a stranger to my heart and me Hold thee from this forever.
source_sent: Haply, when I shall wed, That lord whose hand must take my plight shall carry Half my love with him, half my care and duty.

target_sent: The barbarous Scythian, Or he that makes his generation messes To gorge his appetite, shall to my bosom Be as well neighbored, pitied, and relieved As thou my sometime daughter.
source_sent: Haply, when I shall wed, That lord whose hand must take my plight shall carry Half my love with him, half my care and duty.

target_sent: Thou serv'st me, and I'll love thee.
source_sent: Haply, when I shall wed, That lord whose hand must take my plight shall carry Half my love with him, half my care and duty.

target_sent: O most small fault, How ugly didst thou in Cordelia show, Which, like an engine, wrenched my frame of nature From the fixed place, drew from my heart all love And added to the gall!
source_sent: The jewels of our father, with washed eyes Cordelia leaves you.

target_sent: Do not laugh at me, For, as I am a man, I think this lady To be my child Cordelia.
source_sent: The jewels of our father, with washed eyes Cordelia leaves you.

target_sent: That thou hast sought to make us break our vows -   Which we durst never yet -  and with strained pride To come betwixt our sentence and our power, Which nor our nature nor our place can bear, Our potency made good, take thy reward: Five days we do allot thee for provision To shield thee from disasters of the world, And on the sixth to turn thy hated back Upon our kingdom.
source_sent: Haply, when I shall wed, That lord whose hand must take my plight shall carry Half my love with him, half my care and duty.

target_sent: -   Cordelia, Cordelia, stay a little.
source_sent: The jewels of our father, with washed eyes Cordelia leaves you.

target_sent: There's earnest of thy service.
source_sent: To thy law My services are bound.

target_sent: And art thou come to this?
source_sent: Thou, Nature, art my goddess.

target_sent: Go tell the Duke and 's wife I'd speak with them.
source_sent: The Duke be here tonight?

target_sent: What is 't thou sayst?

target_sent: -   Cordelia, Cordelia, stay a little.

target_sent: The King would speak with Cornwall.

target_sent: Why Gloucester, Gloucester, I'd speak with the Duke of Cornwall and his wife.
source_sent: Have you not spoken 'gainst the Duke of Cornwall?

target_sent: How now, what art thou?

target_sent: -   Hear, Nature, hear, dear goddess, hear!

target_sent: Thou shalt serve me -  if I like thee no worse after dinner.

target_sent: If thou wilt weep my fortunes, take my eyes.

target_sent: A man may see how this world goes with no eyes.

target_sent: Hide thee, thou bloody hand, Thou perjured, and thou simular of virtue That art incestuous.

target_sent: Right noble Burgundy, When she was dear to us, we did hold her so, But now her price is fallen.
source_sent: Here's France and Burgundy, my noble lord.

target_sent: I am the King himself.

target_sent: My lord of Burgundy, We first address toward you, who with this king Hath rivaled for our daughter.

source_sent: I am no less in blood than thou art, Edmund

target_sent: We came crying hither
Thou robèd man of justice, take thy place, And thou, his yokefellow of equity, Bench by his side.
source_sent: -  Want'st thou eyes at trial, madam?

target_sent: When I do stare, see how the subject quakes.
source_sent: I'll look no more Lest my brain turn and the deficient sight Topple down headlong.

target_sent: Thou hotly lusts to use her in that kind For which thou whipp'st her.

target_sent: What is 't thou sayst?
source_sent: Hadst thou been aught but gossamer, feathers, air, So many fathom down precipitating, Thou 'dst shivered like an egg

target_sent: False justicer, why hast thou let her 'scape?
source_sent: -  Want'st thou eyes at trial, madam?

target_sent: Poor naked wretches, wheresoe'er you are, That bide the pelting of this pitiless storm, How shall your houseless heads and unfed sides, Your looped and windowed raggedness defend you From seasons such as these?
source_sent: My face I'll grime with filth, Blanket my loins, elf all my hairs in knots, And with presented nakedness outface The winds and persecutions of the sky.

target_sent: If thou wilt weep my fortunes, take my eyes.
source_sent: -  Want'st thou eyes at trial, madam?

target_sent: Our basest beggars Are in the poorest thing superfluous.
source_sent: The country gives me proof and precedent Of Bedlam beggars who with roaring voices Strike in their numbed and mortifièd arms Pins, wooden pricks, nails, sprigs of rosemary, And, with this horrible object, from low farms, Poor pelting villages, sheepcotes, and mills, Sometime with lunatic bans, sometime with prayers, Enforce their charity.

target_sent: Thy half o' th' kingdom hast thou not forgot, Wherein I thee endowed.
source_sent: That lord that counseled thee To give away thy land, Come place him here by me

target_sent: I will preach to thee.
